chunks.text: Hey everybody in this topic I'm gonna explain format specifiers

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Format specifiers when used in the context of an f string

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: They allow us to format a value based on what flags are inserted

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Following your value you would type a colon and then some flags

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Depending on what flags you insert it will format your output a certain way you could add decimal point precision

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Allocate space

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Zero pad values left justify right justify a central line all sorts of things

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's have some practice. I'll create three prices price one

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: price two

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: price three

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Price one will be three point one four one five nine

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: These values aren't in dollars and cents yet, but they will be

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Price two will be negative nine eight seven dot six five as you can see I'm just making up numbers here

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: price three is

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's display our prices using some f strings

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Price one is

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Placeholder price one

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then we will do this for price two and price three

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Price two is price two price three is price three

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Within our placeholder following the value we can add a colon

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then some flags those flags are the formats specifiers

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: They will format our value a particular way depending on what we insert after the colon

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: To add a decimal point precision you would type after the colon

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: dot

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then the amount of decimals to be displayed maybe two then f meaning floating point number

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's do that with price two and price three colon dot two f

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Price one is now three point one four price two is

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Negative nine hundred eighty seven dot six five price three is twelve point three four

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I think I'm gonna add some dollar signs before the placeholder

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Yeah, that's much better

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: For less precision maybe one decimal place you can change the two to a one

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So point one f

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Each number only displays one decimal point one point six point three

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Whereas in point three F would display three decimal places

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: point one four two point six five zero point three four zero

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Even though price two and price three only have two decimal places in the original numbers

chunks.title: co

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: To allocate space to display a value after the colon add some number some number for that many spaces. How about ten?

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Each value now has a total of ten spaces to display the output one two three four five six seven eight nine ten

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If you were to pre-seat a number with zero while these numbers would be zero padded

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Each number is now zero padded to let justify a value you would use a left-angle bracket

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: All these numbers are now left justified then we have all of the space after

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: They're all uniform right justify would be a right-angle bracket

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And I believe that's the default

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Central line I believe is the carrot symbol

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Yep, our numbers are now centered if you have any positive values and you would like to display a plus sign just use plus

chunks.title: co

chunks.title: co

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Hey everybody in this topic. I'm gonna explain why loops a while loop will execute some code

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: While some condition remains true. Here's an example. We'll use an if statement first

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We will ask a user for their name name equals input

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Enter your name

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If our name is equal to an empty string that means the user didn't type in anything

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's print a message

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: You did not enter your name else

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We will print

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Using an f string. Hello

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Our users name

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If I were to skip this prompt

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We would execute this if statement then we continue with the rest of the program

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: What if I would like to continually prompt the user to type in their name?

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We can't continue until they type in something

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Well, we could replace this if statement with a while loop

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: While this condition is true continue to execute this code within the while loop

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I'm going to reprompt the user to type in a name

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then if we were to exit the while loop then we will print hello whatever your name is

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So let's run this

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Enter your name. I'm going to hit enter you did not enter your name and to your name no no no

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Okay, I give up. I'll type in my first name hit enter. Hello. Whatever your first name is

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: While this condition remains true

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Execute this code

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Potentially forever until this condition is no longer true

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So that's one of the main benefits of a while loop if it's not true

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then you exit out of the while loop and that's why we were able to continue then print our name hello name

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: You do want some way to escape out of the while loop. Otherwise you'll run into what's known as an infinite loop

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So let's say while name is equal to an empty string

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We will print you did not enter your name

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So I'm going to hit enter so we are stuck in an infinite loop

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We can't actually escape this loop. We didn't give ourselves an exit strategy

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: That's why previously we reprompted the user to type in something we're giving them a chance to escape

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: In a way it kind of works like an if statement, but instead of executing some code once it's potentially infinite

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Here's another example this time. Let's ask for a user's age

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Age equals and I will convert the input to an integer

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Enter your age

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We'll need the user to type in a positive number

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: While age is less than zero

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's print a message to let the user know that they can't do that

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Age

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Can't be

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: negative

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then we need some strategy to escape

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's reprompt the user to enter in their age

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Once they type in something that's valid we can escape out of the while loop

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So let's print using an f string

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: you are

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Age

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Years old

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So into your age I'm going to say negative one age can't be negative negative two

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Negative one million

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Okay, I give up how about 21 you are 21 years old. So that was another example

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: While our age variable is less than zero repeat this code forever

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's go over example three

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I'm going to introduce some logical operators

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We will have the user type in a food they like

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Food equals input

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Enter a food you like

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: But in order to escape they need to press Q to quit

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: While food is equal to the letter Q

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Continue this while loop

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: However, I'm going to make one change

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We want to exit the while loop when they press Q

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So you could say while not food equals Q

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So within this while loop let's print the food that they stated that they like

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I'll use an f string

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: You like

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Your variable food

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then we will prompt the user to enter in another food that they like

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Enter another food you like

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Q to quit

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then once we escape the while loop we will print just by

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Enter a food you like Q to quit

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I like pizza

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: You like pizza

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I like sushi

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: You like sushi

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I like ramen

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: You like ramen

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Okay, this program is kind of lame so I'm going to press Q to quit

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And we escape the while loop we have printed by

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So you could do something while something is not true by using the not logical operator

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: All right last example example for

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We will use the or logical operator

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We'll ask a user to type in a number between 1 and 10

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's say num equals input

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Enter a number between 1 through 10

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then I will typecast the input as an integer

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: While our number is less than 1 or our number is greater than 10

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's reprompt the user

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's print using an f string

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Our variable num is not valid

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then we will reprompt the user

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Enter a number between 1 and 10

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Once we escape the while loop then we will print our number

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Using an f string your number is our variable num

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Enter a number between 1 through 10

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: 0 is not valid

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Negative 1

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Nope

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Your number is 5

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: That's an example of how you can add a logical operators to wild loops

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: While this condition is true

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Or this condition is true

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Execute this code forever

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: All right everybody so those are wild loops

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: A wild loop will execute some code

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: While some condition remains true

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: It's fairly useful for verifying user input

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: If a user types in some input that is not valid you can reprompt them

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And there's many other uses that we'll discuss in the future

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: But yeah those are wild loops in python

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Why hello everybody

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: In today's video we'll be creating a compound interest calculator in python

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: For those that don't know

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Interest is a charge for the privilege of borrowing money to some individual or organization

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: When you place money in a bank account you typically accrue interest

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We'll create a program to tell you what your new balance will be

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: After accruing interest for so many years

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: But the user is going to decide the initial principle

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: That's the investment

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: The rate of interest and the time in years

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: That this balance has been accruing interest

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: So let's begin

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Let's declare three variables

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: A principle

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: A rate that is rate of interest

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: And time time will be in years

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We've recently learned about wild loops

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: I would like to include those within this program

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Just so we get the hang of using them

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We will ask the user to type in an initial principle investment

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We will continue to prompt the user to type in a principle that's above zero

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Our condition will be while principle is less than or equal to zero

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: We will take our principle

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Assign it some user input

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Enter the principle amount

chunks.title: co
chunks.text: Then we would like to type cast our input
